On Tue, 12 Oct 2004 16:18:35 +0100, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@...> wrote:
> 
> 
> 
> At 15:49 12/10/2004, you wrote:
> 
> >As a side note, what I hear in all this discussion is an effort to
> >sort of re-invent backpropagation...  The point being that if we take
> >a moment to recognize that that is what we are doing, we might be able
> >to draw from what has already been done in that field.
> 
> Hi,
>          I don't get the connection with back-propagation -- can you explain?
> 
>          Ian

Sure...let me quote from one of your posts...

>>There actually is a third, more sophisticated method for getting
>>weight mutation parameters, which is to measure the success of
>>mutations in various directions in the multidimensional space and
>>actually construct a model of the most promising mutation trajectory
>>based on the experience over past generations (as a multi-dimensional
>>probability distribution).  That has recently popped up in ES as well,
>>though the math behind it is not simple at all.

>But that is a step away from the basis of an evolutionary search and
>towards a gradient-based method.  Gradient-based methods are
>well-established and the choice for many problems, but they have certain
>weaknesses which evolutionary methods address... IMHO, that is.

Basically, I was saying what you were saying...that this takes us one
step closer to back-propagation / gradient-based methods.

And that perhaps we might learn from both the successes and failures
of that technique.  But that we would do well do do so conscientiously
as opposed to re-inventing it in an effort to make improvements to our
current approach.  Make sense?

-- John
